dc:description:
*NSMCE2* is located on chromosome 8q24.13 and encodes a SUMO E3 ligase that functions within the SMC5/6 complex, essential for DNA damage repair, resolution of replication stress, and chromosome stability. It promotes SUMOylation of SMC6, a process enhanced upon DNA damage, linking its activity to the DNA damage response.

Pathogenic variants in *NSMCE2* were first reported in two patients with clinical features suggestive of Seckel syndrome, a recessive disorder characterized by poor growth, microcephaly, and intellectual disability, by Payne et al. (2014, PMID: 25105364). Biallelic  pathogenic variants in SMC5 that is another cardinal component of SMC5/6 also disrupt NSMCE2 function that was seen in two publications with microcephaly, short stature, and developmental delay due to impaired binding with SMC5, SLF2, and SMC6 (Grange et al, 2022, PMID: 36333305; Zhu et al, PMID: 36627765).

Loss of *NSMCE2* results in stalled replication forks, defective double-strand break formation, and chromosomal instability, evidenced by increased micronuclei and nucleoplasmic bridges in fibroblasts. Hydroxyurea treatment exacerbates replication stress, and BrdU pulse-chase experiments in patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines reveal impaired S-phase progression. These findings underscore *NSMCE2*’s critical role in genome maintenance and human developmental disorders.

Two frameshift variants have been reported in humans and the information of four other variants (frameshift, nonsense and exonic deletion) in *NSMCE2* is available in the ClinVar database. This gene-disease relationship is supported by biochemical function studies, protein interaction, non-human model organism studies, and functional alteration analysis. (Payne et al. 2014, PMID: 25105364; Atkins 2020, PMID: 33200984; Zhu et al, PMID: 36627765).

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged.  This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on the meeting date February 5th, 2025 (SOP Version 11).

evidence.dc:description: p.Ser116Leufs*18 mutation occurs between the N-terminal helix bundle and the SP-RING domain and introduces 18 unstructured amino acids

p.Ala234Glufs*4 mutation lies at the C terminus of the domain, removing the 14 C-terminal amino acids of the protein (Figure 2A) and thereby disrupting the C-terminal α helix formed by residues 223–240
Consistent with its reduced expression and lack of SP-RING domain, auto–SUMO-ligase activity of p.Ser116Leufs*18 was virtually undetectable.
p.Ala234Glufs*4 mutation lies at the C terminus of the domain, removing the 14 C-terminal amino acids of the protein and thereby disrupting the C-terminal α helix formed by residues 223–240

SMC5/6 complex comprises an E3 SUMO ligase, NSMCE2, which interacts with a region of the coiled coil domain of SMC5. Mutations within genes encoding SMC complex components are associated with human developmental defects. Collectively known as cohesinopathies, mutations in cohesin components lead to an array of abnormalities, including growth retardation and cognitive impairment. genetic variations in other components of the SMC5/6 complex, including SMC5, are potentially associated with congenital defects including heart and neurodevelopmental anomalies
evidence.rdfs:label: Smc5 conditional knockout

evidence.dc:description: coinjection of R372del variant identified in the patient failed to rescue the smc5 KO phenotype
evidence.rdfs:label: smc5 KO zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Injection of splice-site MOs targeted to Nsmce2 markedly reduce body size compared with that of control-injected or uninjected WT embryos. Coinjection of WT human NSMCE2/MMS21 mRNA (WT rescue) with nsmce2-targeting MOs attenuated the dwarf phenotype observed in the nsmce2 morphant alone (morph). In contrast, coinjection of either human NSMCE2/MMS21 S116Lfs*18, human NSMCE2/MMS21 A234Efs*4, together with nsmce2-targeting MOs did not affect the severity of the dwarf phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: nsmce2/mms21 morphant zebrafish rescue

evidence.dc:description:
Ser116Leufs*18 undergoes nonsense mediated mRNA decay
Ala234Glufs*4 undergoes truncation

Delayed DNA Synthesis Recovery

1. BrdU pulse-chase experiments in patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines (LCLs) showed impaired S-phase progression, indicating problems in completing DNA replication.

Defective DNA Damage Response

1. Reduced formation of Bloom syndrome helicase (BLM) foci in response to HU and ionizing radiation (IR), suggesting defective homologous recombination repair (HRR).
2. Increased sister chromatid exchanges (SCE) following UV exposure, indicating improper resolution of replication-associated DNA damage.
evidence.rdfs:label: BrdU pulse-chase experiments

evidence.dc:description:
Higher frequencies of micronuclei (MN) and nucleoplasmic bridges (NPB) in dermal fibroblasts, indicating chromosome mis-segregation.

Increased MN and NPB were further exacerbated after hydroxyurea (HU) treatment, which induces replication stress.
evidence.rdfs:label: Micronuclei and nucleoplasmic bridges

evidence.dc:description: mutations in NSMCE3 result in immunodeficiency and lung disease, where patient-derived cells exhibit hallmarks of chromosome instability and replication stress
evidence.rdfs:label: Smc5 is conditionally knocked out (cKO) in the neocortex

evidence.dc:description:
In primary fibroblasts from an adult patient with microcephalic primordial dwarfism, chromosomal instability and insulin resistance was analysed. The patient had a homozygous in‐frame deletion of Arg372 in SMC5, one of the core subunits of the SMC5/6 complex. SMC5: p.Arg372del alteration showed the interaction between mutant SMC5 and NSMCE2 was ∼70% of that between WT and NSMCE2 by coimmunoprecipitation. 

Position of the p.Arg372del variant located in the binding domain of SMC5 with the NSMCE2 protein. There is strong conservation of the deleted amino acid, p.Arg37.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoprecipitation
